text: Reteaming is hard. Reorgs are hard. You can't lump them all into one thing with oh, it's all great all the time. No, it's not. If we could just build the software, deliver to the customer, get the product market fit, hey, have we delighted them or not? If only it could be that easy. No, we have the people layer, so let's focus there too.
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: At the opening of the podcast, Heidi sets the foundation for why organizational change and team restructuring matters. She acknowledges that while the ultimate goal is building great products and achieving product-market fit, there's an additional complexity layer that many companies overlook - the human element of how teams are organized and how they change over time.
vocabulary_highlights: lump them all into one thing
text_ko: 팀 재구성(reteaming)은 정말 힘들어요. 조직 개편(reorgs)도 마찬가지고요. 이걸 다 한꺼번에 놓고 '아, 항상 다 잘돼요'라고 말할 수는 없어요. 아니에요, 그렇지 않아요. 만약 그냥 소프트웨어만 만들고 고객에게 전달해서 제품-시장 적합(product-market fit)만 맞추면, 고객을 정말 기쁘게 했는지 여부만 보면 된다면 얼마나 좋겠어요. 그렇게만 쉬웠으면 좋겠지만, 사람 측면(people layer)이 있으니 거기도 집중해야 해요.
text_zh: 重组团队很难搞，公司重组也很难搞。你不能把这些事儿都混在一起说"哎呀，反正都挺好的"。不是这样的。要是我们只要专心写代码、交付给客户、找到产品市场契合点(product market fit)，看看用户满不满意就行了，那该多好。要真能这么简单就好了。但问题是还有人的因素在里面，所以我们也得把这块儿重视起来。
text_es: Reorganizar equipos es difícil. Las reestructuraciones son difíciles. No puedes meter todo en el mismo saco diciendo "ay, todo es genial siempre". No, no lo es. Si pudiéramos simplemente desarrollar el software, entregárselo al cliente, conseguir el encaje producto-mercado (product market fit), oye, ¿los hemos dejado contentos o no? Ojalá fuera así de sencillo. Pero no, tenemos el factor humano, así que enfoquémonos también en eso.

text: I think a lot of the things that I would read about teams just are naturally focused on, well, you want to build things that customers love. You want it to be an enjoyable experience, you want to deliver on time. There's a reason we're there as a business, but there's also a lot of company building that happens in building the people structures and just when you go from one to many to a multitude, there's a lot of work that goes into it.
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Lenny asks Heidi to elaborate on the 'people layer' concept she mentioned earlier. Heidi explains that while most business advice focuses on product delivery and customer satisfaction, there's an equally important but often overlooked aspect of company building - designing and managing the human structures and team organizations as companies scale from small startups to large organizations.
vocabulary_highlights: from one to many to a multitude
text_ko: 제가 팀(teams)에 대해 읽는 많은 얘기들은 대체로 '고객(customers)이 좋아할 것을 만들어라', '사용자 경험이 즐거워야 한다', '제때 전달하라' 같은 데 초점이 맞춰져 있어요. 사업(business)으로서 우리가 존재하는 이유가 분명 있긴 하지만, 인력 구조(people structures)를 세우는 등 회사를 만들어 가는 과정(company building)에서도 할 일이 정말 많아요. 특히 한 사람에서 여러 명으로, 그다음 훨씬 많은 규모로 확장할 때 들어가는 일이 엄청 많죠.
text_zh: 我觉得很多关于团队管理的文章，讲的都是那些基本的东西，比如要做出客户喜欢的产品，要让用户体验好，要按时交付。这些确实是我们做生意的根本，但是呢，真正搭建公司的过程中，还有很多是关于人的架构建设。你想想，从一个人到一个小团队，再到一大帮人，这中间要做的工作可多了去了。
text_es: Creo que muchas de las cosas que leo sobre equipos se enfocan naturalmente en lo obvio: quieres crear productos que los clientes amen, quieres que sea una experiencia agradable, quieres entregar a tiempo. Hay una razón por la cual estamos ahí como negocio, pero también hay muchísimo trabajo de construcción empresarial que pasa cuando desarrollas las estructuras de personal, y cuando pasas de uno a muchos a una multitud, hay un montón de trabajo detrás de eso.

text: So we rolled these whiteboards out and it had the team structure with everyone's names on it. It had the name of the team, the mission of the team, how many open slots for hiring across all of these different teams, and then people's names in their existing team positions. And people were invited to look, give feedback. They identified mistakes that we had in the design, 'Oh, this team might be better over here and here's why.' And people had the opportunity to see opportunities within their own company that they might say, 'Hey, I'm interested in this, might I be considered for this?'
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Lenny asks about how to take advantage of reorg opportunities for career advancement. Heidi shares a story about transparent reorganization at Procore, where they used 'whiteboard reteaming' - a method inspired by Spotify where leadership visualized the new team structure on whiteboards and invited all 80 affected employees to provide input and express interest in different roles before finalizing the changes.
vocabulary_highlights: might I be considered for this
text_ko: 그래서 저희는 화이트보드(whiteboards)를 공개했어요. 거기에는 팀 구조(team structure)와 각 사람 이름이 적혀 있었고, 팀 이름, 팀 미션(mission), 여러 팀에 걸쳐 몇 자리의 채용 공석(open slots)이 있는지도 표시돼 있었어요. 사람들은 자신의 현재 맡은 자리도 확인할 수 있었고, 와서 보고 피드백을 달라고 초대했어요. 그러다 보니 설계상의 실수들을 발견하더라고요 — “아, 이 팀은 여기 있는 것보다 저쪽이 더 맞을 것 같아요, 이유는요…” 하고요. 또 직원들은 회사 안에서 “저거 관심 있는데, 저 자리에 고려해주실 수 있나요?”라고 직접 말할 기회도 갖게 됐어요.
text_zh: 所以我们就把这些白板推出去了，上面有团队架构，每个人的名字都在上面。有团队名称，团队使命，各个团队还有多少招聘名额，然后现有团队成员的名字和职位。大家都可以过来看看，给反馈。他们发现了我们设计中的一些问题，比如"哦，这个团队放在那边可能更好，原因是这样的。"而且大家有机会看到公司内部的机会，可能会说"嘿，我对这个感兴趣，能不能考虑一下我？"
text_es: Entonces sacamos estas pizarras y tenían toda la estructura de equipos con los nombres de todos. Tenía el nombre del equipo, la misión del equipo, cuántas vacantes había para contratar en todos estos diferentes equipos, y después los nombres de las personas en sus puestos actuales. E invitamos a la gente a que echara un vistazo y diera su opinión. Identificaron errores que teníamos en el diseño, "Ah, este equipo tal vez funcionaría mejor acá y te explico por qué." Y la gente tuvo la oportunidad de ver oportunidades dentro de su propia empresa donde pudieran decir, "Oye, esto me interesa, ¿me considerarían para esto?"

text: There's another framework that I really like. I don't think it's in my book, but I've written about it in my new book, but it's called RIDE. And we had a chief people officer at Procore and she's now at UKG, Pat Wadors. She taught us the RIDE framework for decision making clarity and it's who's requesting the change, who can give input to the change, who's the decider on the change, and who's going to execute on the change?
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Lenny asks about how to manage the complexity of involving teams in reorganization decisions. Heidi introduces the RIDE framework (Request, Input, Decide, Execute) created by Pat Wadors, which clarifies roles and responsibilities in organizational changes. This framework helps avoid confusion about who has decision-making authority versus who can provide input during team restructuring processes.
text_ko: 제가 정말 좋아하는 다른 프레임워크가 하나 있어요. 제 책에는 아마 안 실렸던 것 같은데, 새 책에는 썼어요. RIDE 프레임워크(RIDE)라고 해요. Procore에 있을 때 Chief People Officer(최고 인사 책임자)이셨고 지금은 UKG에 계신 팻 와더스(Pat Wadors)님이 우리에게 의사결정을 더 명확하게 하는 RIDE 프레임워크를 알려주셨어요. RIDE는 누가 변경을 요청하는지, 누가 변경에 대해 의견을 줄 수 있는지, 누가 최종 결정을 내리는지, 그리고 누가 실행할지를 구분한 거예요.
text_zh: 还有一个框架我特别喜欢。我记得之前那本书里没写，但新书里有提到，叫RIDE。我们以前在Procore有个首席人事官Pat Wadors，她现在在UKG，是她教给我们这个RIDE框架(RIDE framework)，专门用来理清决策流程的。就是说，谁提出要做这个改变，谁可以提意见，谁来拍板决定，还有谁负责去执行？
text_es: Hay otro modelo que me gusta mucho. No creo que esté en mi libro, pero sí lo escribí en mi nuevo libro, y se llama RIDE. Teníamos una directora de personas en Procore y ahora está en UKG, Pat Wadors. Ella nos enseñó el modelo RIDE para tener claridad en la toma de decisiones y es: quién está pidiendo el cambio, quién puede dar su opinión sobre el cambio, quién es el que decide sobre el cambio, y quién va a ejecutar el cambio.

text: So taking a team off to the side, giving that team process freedom. They didn't want us distracted from the drag. When you're working on an existing product line, you get this cadence and it can become a mature cadence. Maybe people work in two weeks or one week now, but when you're working on something new, you need faster iteration loops. And our founders knew that need.
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Heidi shares the story of how Expertcity (which became GoTo products) successfully pivoted by using an 'isolation' reteaming pattern. When their original marketplace product failed, leadership created a small isolated team to work on GoToMyPC with complete process freedom. Heidi explains that existing product teams develop established rhythms that work for mature products, but new innovations require much faster iteration cycles.
text_ko: 그래서 한 팀을 따로 떼어 놓고, 그 팀에겐 프로세스 자율성(process freedom)을 줬어요. 그들은 우리가 핵심 업무에서 벗어나 방해받길 원하지 않았어요. 기존 제품 라인에서 일할 땐 일정한 리듬(cadence)이 생기고 그 리듬이 익숙해질 수 있어요. 요즘은 사람들 대부분 2주 단위나 1주 단위로 일하지만, 새로운 걸 만들 때는 더 빠른 반복 주기(iteration loop)가 필요해요. 우리 창업자들은 그 필요성을 잘 알고 있었어요.
text_zh: 所以把团队拉出来单独搞，给他们流程上的自由度。他们不想让我们被那些拖后腿的事情分心。你在做现有产品线的时候，会有个固定节奏，而且可能变得很成熟很稳定。可能大家习惯了两周或者一周一个周期，但是做新东西的时候，你需要更快的迭代循环(iteration loops)。我们创始人很清楚这个需求。
text_es: Así que apartamos a un equipo, les dimos libertad total en sus procesos. No querían que nos distrajéramos de las trabas del día a día. Cuando trabajas en una línea de productos que ya existe, agarras un ritmo y puede volverse un ritmo muy establecido. A lo mejor la gente trabaja en sprints de dos semanas o una semana, pero cuando trabajas en algo nuevo, necesitas ciclos de iteración mucho más rápidos. Y nuestros fundadores sabían perfectamente esa necesidad.

text: And so, one, separate location. There's another story in the book about a team that incubated a product idea within Citrix and they were in a garage of all places, so they were really isolated. But just put the team in a different region, make it that area. That's number one. Number two, tell other people not to disturb this team. That's key. And hearing it from a leader is really, really important.
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Lenny asks about how to make isolated innovation teams successful, since the 'startup within a company' approach often fails. Heidi provides concrete advice for the isolation reteaming pattern: physically separate the team, have leadership explicitly protect them from interruptions, and ensure they have process freedom to work differently from the main organization.
text_ko: 그래서 첫째, 장소를 따로 떼어 놓으세요. 책에 시트릭스 안에서 제품 아이디어를 인큐베이팅(incubated)하던 팀 이야기가 나오는데, 믿기 힘들게도 차고에 있었어요 — 완전히 고립돼 있었죠. 팀을 아예 다른 지역에 두세요. 그게 첫 번째예요. 둘째, 다른 사람들에게 이 팀을 방해하지 말라고 알려 주세요. 이게 핵심이에요. 그리고 리더가 직접 그렇게 말해 주는 게 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 所以说，第一点，要单独找个地方。书里还有个故事，讲的是Citrix内部有个团队孵化产品想法，他们竟然是在车库里办公，真的是完全隔离开了。就是要把团队放到不同的区域，给他们划出专门的地盘。这是第一点。第二点，要告诉其他人别去打扰这个团队。这很关键。而且这话得从领导嘴里说出来，这真的非常非常重要。
text_es: Entonces, primero, que estén en un lugar aparte. Hay otra historia en el libro sobre un equipo que desarrolló una idea de producto dentro de Citrix y estaban en un garaje, imagínate, o sea, súper aislados. Pero simplemente pon al equipo en otra zona, que sea su espacio. Eso es lo primero. Lo segundo, diles a los demás que no molesten a este equipo. Eso es clave. Y que lo diga un líder es súper, súper importante.

text: So you need to shed their skin of the other things that they're working on. If you take a bigger picture, kind of forest through the trees picture, you want people pairing and switching pairs so they're not single owners of the system. So when they have an opportunity to do something that could be really important to the company beyond one of these isolated teams, they can fade out and not be the only owner that has to transfer knowledge and then field questions for two years on how that system works.
speaker: Heidi Helfand
context: Continuing her advice on successful isolation teams, Heidi explains how companies can prepare for this type of reteaming by building knowledge redundancy. She advocates for pair programming and regular switching of pairs so that no single person becomes the sole owner of critical systems, which makes it easier for people to join special projects without leaving knowledge gaps behind.
text_ko: 그래서 그 사람들이 하고 있는 다른 업무들의 부담은 덜어줘야 해요. 좀 더 큰 그림(big picture)에서 보면, 사람들이 페어링(pairing)을 하고 페어를 바꿔가면서(switching pairs) 일해서 누구도 시스템의 유일한 담당자(single owner)이 되지 않게 해야 해요. 그래야 한 사람이 고립된 팀을 넘어 회사에 정말 중요한 일을 맡게 될 기회가 생겼을 때 역할을 줄여 빠져나와도 되고, 지식 이전(knowledge transfer)을 혼자 모두 떠맡고 앞으로 2년 동안 시스템 작동 방식에 대한 문의(field questions)에 홀로 답해야 하는 상황을 피할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 所以你得让他们放下手头的其他事情。从大局来看，就是要让大家结对工作，而且要轮换搭档，这样就不会出现某个系统只有一个人懂的情况。这样一来，当有机会去做对公司真正重要的事情，而不是局限在某个孤立的小团队里时，他们就可以顺利脱身，不用担心自己是唯一的负责人，还得花两年时间去做知识交接和回答各种系统问题。
text_es: Entonces necesitas que se despeguen de las otras cosas en las que están trabajando. Si lo ves desde una perspectiva más amplia, digamos el panorama general, lo que buscas es que la gente trabaje en parejas y vaya rotando esas parejas para que no sean los únicos dueños del sistema. Así, cuando tengan la oportunidad de hacer algo que realmente pueda ser importante para la empresa, más allá de estos equipos aislados, pueden ir saliendo gradualmente sin ser los únicos responsables que tienen que transferir el conocimiento y después estar respondiendo preguntas durante dos años sobre cómo funciona ese sistema.
